subject: Re: [junit] Re: running test methods in order
msgSnippet: That tells me what technology you re using, but that doesn t tell me what you re trying to test. I want to test the create operation on an entity bean. CMP?
messageBody:
That tells me what technology you're using, but that doesn't tell me
what you're trying to test.

"I want to test the create operation on an entity bean."

CMP? BMP?

If it's a CMP bean, then the only things you can get wrong are:
* the bean/table mapping
* EJB queries
* other deployment settings

All these things are specified within an XML document, so you can
always test that the XML document has the correct fragment of XML for
your entity bean, but I wouldn't test the entity bean itself -- not in
a Programmer Test. Save that for a Customer Test. From your
perspective, there are no real Programmer Tests beyond checking the
deployment descriptor.

If it's a BMP bean, then you have to test the primitive operations:
* ejbLoad, ejbStore, ejbCreate, ejbRemove

Since they are just JDBC with possibly a little JNDI, your Programmer
Tests should focus on the bean implementation and simulate the
container by exercising your primitive operations. Even then, it should
concentrate on getting the SQL right and processing a ResultSet
correctly. You can do both without the database. It may seem easier to
do them with the database, but that's a short-term view. During the
lifetime of an entire project, it is easier to test that stuff entirely
in memory.

Best of luck.

So said belingueres <gaby@...> on 1/31/2003
--------------------

>I'm testing the CRUD (Creation, Retrieval, Update, Delete) operations
>on entity beans (which are acceded by a session facade)
>
>Gabriel
>
>--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@d...> wrote:
>> Simple question: what do you think will break? Do you think the
>> database will break? Your SQL? Your use of JDBC?
>>
>> You don't need to test with the actual database, unless you're
>testing
>> the actual database... I'm assuming you're writing Programmer Tests
>> here. If not, then feel free to ignore me.
>>
>> Good luck.
>>
>> So said belingueres <gaby@i...> on 2003-01-29
>> --------------------
>>
>> >Hi,
>> >
>> >I need to test a simple insertion of a tuple into a data base
>table.
>> >
>> >First I set the table empty, then I test that an specific tuple is
>> >correctly inserted.
>> >Then, I try to insert the same tuple again, which would result in
>an
>> >exception, since its primary key is duplicated.
>> >
>> >Those tow tests I did it in two different testXXX() methods in the
>> >TestCase: testInsert() and testDuplicated()
>> >
>> >The thing is that JUnit runs first the testDuplicated() method and
>> >then the testInsert(), so the two tests fails!
>> >
>> >How can I assure myself that the two test methods run in a
>particular
>> >order?
>> >
>> >Is this a good testing practice?
>> >
>> >Thanks in advance,
>> >Gabriel
